simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Introspection Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "GraphQL introspection enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found __schema in response data - introspection queries are allowed"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: GraphQL Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The API responded to an introspection-style query by returning the GraphQL schema (the \"__schema\" object and its \"types\" list). This exposes the server's type definitions and internal schema metadata (including introspection types like __Type, __Field, __InputValue), which allows an attacker to enumerate available types, fields, and inputs and to craft targeted queries. While introspection itself is not an immediate code-execution or data-injection vulnerability, it significantly lowers the effort required to discover sensitive fields and construct queries for data exfiltration or privilege escalation. Recommended mitigations: disable or restrict introspection in production environments, require authentication/authorization for schema queries, implement query complexity and depth limits, and log/monitor unusual GraphQL discovery activity.", "evidence": "Response contains a top-level \"__schema\" object with a \"types\" array (e.g. \"data\": { \"__schema\": { \"types\": [ { \"name\": \"Boolean\" }, { \"name\": \"Continent\" }, ..., { \"name\": \"__Type\" } ] } }).", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "GraphQL Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Response contains a top-level \"__schema\" object with a \"types\" array (e.g. \"data\": { \"__schema\": { \"types\": [ { \"name\": \"Boolean\" }, { \"name\": \"Continent\" }, ..., { \"name\": \"__Type\" } ] } }).", "explanation": "The API responded to an introspection-style query by returning the GraphQL schema (the \"__schema\" object and its \"types\" list). This exposes the server's type definitions and internal schema metadata (including introspection types like __Type, __Field, __InputValue), which allows an attacker to enumerate available types, fields, and inputs and to craft targeted queries. While introspection itself is not an immediate code-execution or data-injection vulnerability, it significantly lowers the effort required to discover sensitive fields and construct queries for data exfiltration or privilege escalation. Recommended mitigations: disable or restrict introspection in production environments, require authentication/authorization for schema queries, implement query complexity and depth limits, and log/monitor unusual GraphQL discovery activity."}}]
